Journal Story: Hello all and welcome to my AT Trail journal,If you've reached this point, you're either curious or confused about what Charlie is up to in 2017. I've set a goal for myself to hike the Appalachian Trail (AT) this year. All 2185 miles of trail from Georgia to Maine. I've been letting a few folks know of this goal and have had a variety of questions and responses.  To help with your confusion or curiosity, I've prepared a best of list of questions and responses: Are you nuts? - Probably, but I'll be in great company of other AT "nuts", so should blend in with the AT community.Will you carry a gun? - Nope. Stuff does happen on the trail, but statistically, I'll be much safer than I'd ever be in a populated area. How much food will you carry? or Are you carrying 6 months worth of food? - I'll be carrying about 5- 10 days worth of food, and will resupply at the many towns that the AT intersects.What will you eat? Follow by comment "Just thinking about your trip makes me hungry" - Simple to cook (boil only) meals; rice & beans, pasta, soups, inst oatmeal, roadkill, etc... And calorie dense items: nuts, peanut butter, cheese, and the occasional junk food items. Think carbs (simple and complex), protein, and fats. How long will this take? - Goal is to average 14 miles a day, which would take about 5 months. But I'd be good to make it to Maine within 6 months.When are you going? - Around March 27th is my start date. Is anyone going with you? - No and yes. No one is hiking with me the whole way, but I will be meeting up with many hiking friends and family along the way. Especially in the N.East sections where I'm from. My brother in law Bill and nephew Jordan will be hiking with me for a week thru NC. How much weight will you carry? - My base (w/out food & water) pack weight target goal is less than 15 lbs. Total limit is to stay under 30 Lbs. This gives me 15 lbs for food, water, and any extra seasonal gear I may need.What will you do about bears (or other scary animal)? - Take their picture if I can. Bear attacks on this side of the country are rare, and bears are usually more scared of humans, or only interested in my food than me. Those are the big and weighty questions I've had so far. I'll post more as they come up. Check back later if you want to find out about what I'm doing to get ready, gear I'm checking out, meals I'm testing, or other pre trip goings on. Charlie

Hello all,The quest for Georgia to Maine has officially begun. I hope you had a chance to read my first blog post, with some FAQs about my plans for an AT hike this year. If I didn't answer your burning question, drop me a note or check back on this blog as I collect and answer additional FAQs.   The picture in this post the great AMC Worcester 20's and 30's group on a winter overnight in the white mountains. Thanks Claudine, Noah, Ted, Mike, Seth, and Marlies for embracing winter with me this weekend. It was a great brush up on my backpacking skills and a blast to bag a couple of White mountain peaks with you. One interesting observation has been how people have been reacting to my plans for an AT thru hike. I should also preface that I also share the news that I left my job of 22 years to enable my AT odyssey.  The reactions fall into three categories: 1. "That's awesome" - This has been the typical reaction from friends, family, and co-workers. People are genuinely happy and excited for me. I believe they're happy that I'm able to pursue a life goal, and have the courage to leave a secure, well paying, and great job to do something different and exciting. 2. "You're doing what?" Or a long silence - This is a struggle to understand if I'm kidding or crazy. The thought of stepping into the woods for about 5 to 6 months is not a goal they share. That's OK, I truly hope that I can educate them on how our outdoor spaces and the AT are special places to experience and protect. Maybe they'll get the hiking bug and hit the trail for a couple hours or a couple nights3. "Go fuck yourself" - I love these reactions. This is a pure and unfiltered emotional response. They usually follow up the initial comments with some details on how they'd love to leave their job and do something totally different. They're good friends and I hope they realize that if I can do this, so can they. Hopefully I inspire them to get off their butts and do something to fulfill their dream.

Hello all,I'm still in pre-AT hike mode. I've been very busy with prep and finishing up several commitments at base camp (my home).   I'd love to get on the trail now, but I'm committed to several ski trips I planned before my AT hike adventure. Also, I don't mind missing the winter weather. I don't mind backpacking in cold and snow, but don't believe carrying all that extra winter gear will set me up for success. My official start date is March 28th. I've booked a flight down to Atlanta on Spirit Air for March 27th.   Spirit Air was the cheapest flight option (by about 30% less than Delta), and from what I hear, may be the riskiest part of my AT hike adventure.   I'll be using the next several weeks to get myself in backpacking shape, tweak my gear (shopping!), do some addition research, and practice some skills like cooking, tent setup, etc...One question I've been asked several times is what's my trail name. A trail name is a nickname bestowed upon hikers, especially thru hikers. The trail name is meant to capture the essence of a hiker's personality, character, or some event. The name is usually something colorful and humorous.    An example trail name is AWOL. Which is guide book author David Miller who took a leave of absence to thru hike the AT. I've been an avid hiker and backpacker for several years, and am sorry to say I don't have a trail name. At least not one that has stuck with me. I've had several suggestions (Forest Gump, Papa Smurf, Single Brad Pitt), but none that seem to work. Can you help me out with a Trail Name suggestion?   If you have a good name that captures the essence of Charlie, send it my way. Else I may need to default to the Brad Pitt suggestion. Thanks,Charlie

Hello and welcome to my AT blog, I'm 11 days from being on the trail and am sweating the details. One huge item I'm sweating is gear. I've spent the last 5 months researching and buying gear. It's been lots of fun, but I've come to realize that even the best gear can't walk itself to Maine.   Here is my dilemma, all my gear is great but I can't fit it all into my light weight and expensive backpack. I've set a goal of 30 lbs of gear food and water. I'm coming in closer to 35 lbs. Buy a bigger packpack, no In need to stop shopping and start hiking.   The solution is obvious; loose 5 lbs of gear. What can I give up?   I need the big three (Tent, Sleeping bag, and backpack)But can cut back on some clothing (about a lb).I've ditched the insulated coffee mug, I even cut the handle off the mug to save weight, but 3.5 oz saved is a good start.What else should I ditch? Treking umbrella? camp shoes, Underwear? electric can opener? Below is my gear analysis (let me know if you want the excel version). I've spent the last 5 months researching and weighting (literally) all my gear options. Now the hard part; gear diet. Just like the bride and the wedding dress, I'm going to make it fit (and look radiant)Regards,CharlieItem        Specific Item        Cost        Weight oz        a cost        a Hello all,Thanks if you've been following me on this Blog (Trailjournals.com/charliea), but I've come to realize that this site is not mobile friendly.I love being part of the Thru hiker community on this site, but can't see myself struggling on the trail to make updates via my phone. Or waiting several days to get computer access in a trail town. I'm making the big Blog move to Facebook (yeh, Mark Zuckerburg wins this round).You can follow my adventure at "Charlie AT Hike" group I've created within FB.It's a closed group, so you'll need to ask for permission to join (which will be granted as soon as feasible)I'm packed and ready to go, and will be on the trail in two days. Regards,Charlie
